title: Riot should consider revising their "zero tolerance on homophobic slurs" policy. Here's why.

replies.body: "Wholesome jokes" do not use language with a decades-long history of hatred and homophobia behind it. Full stop.

> [{quoted}](name=The Djinn,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=E5VEhPeY,comment-id=0001,timestamp=2018-03-12T23:23:28.017+0000)
>
> "Wholesome jokes" do not use language with a decades-long history of hatred and homophobia behind it. Full stop.

As I said, perhaps in my instance a punishment was needed. Two weeks though? I'm not arguing that Riot should do away with banning people who say a slur - that would be stupid. But the severity. If you've been banned before, then sure, maybe 14 days. But the fact that I have not been toxic in 4+ years of playing, then offhandedly say that and get 2 week banned, when there's people calling their teammates "pieces of shit, useless, etc" and AFK all in the same game not get any sort of punishment is absurd. Usually you get a warning, chat restriction, 1 day, 3 day, 7 day, 14 day. I skipped all of those steps and went straight to 14 day. Getting a warning before jumping 2 weeks would have been nice, especially given my history of never once being toxic.

> [{quoted}](name=SWATCOLE,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=E5VEhPeY,comment-id=00010000,timestamp=2018-03-13T00:30:39.384+0000)...then offhandedly say that and get 2 week banned, when there's people calling their teammates "pieces of shit, useless, etc" and AFK all in the same game not get any sort of punishment is absurd. 

While I agree those players are violating rules and should face punishments, those terms are insults against a single individual.

When you use this particular form of hate speech, it is not only an attack on the individual being targeted but also an insult against an entire section of the population, as you're equating part of their identity with something negative enough that it can be used as an insult. It is pretty much identical in usage to the n-word or any other racial/religious hate speech.

>I skipped all of those steps and went straight to 14 day.

You got an immediate 14-day ban because hate speech is a zero tolerance policy, for the reasons mentioned above. It is above and beyond a normal insult.

> [{quoted}](name=The Djinn,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=E5VEhPeY,comment-id=000100000000,timestamp=2018-03-13T00:37:56.888+0000)

It is pretty much identical in usage to the n-word or any other racial/religious hate speech.
> 
> You got an immediate 14-day ban because hate speech is a zero tolerance policy, for the reasons mentioned above. It is above and beyond a normal insult.

A lot of it is lost in translation over text, as you can't tell if they're being sarcastic/joking/serious/etc. I wasn't using it as a legitimate insult, but I can 100% see why it's seen that way over text at face value. When I tell my friends to "oh fuck off", I don't mean it as a real insult. The same with this. If I was using it as an insult, then yes - you'd also be insulting the whole gay community. But I wasn't. Nonetheless, you can't tell that over text and I understand why I was banned, even if I disagree with it. 

That's not where I see a flaw in Riot's policy. I see it in the fact that you are in no way able to try to get it repealed. The other guy was insulting himself. You shouldn't get banned 14 day banned for insulting yourself. Bronze players are seen as bad, and that's negative enough to be used as an insult. So, according to your definition it's "hate speech". Calling yourself Bronze after a bad play doesn't get you banned, and neither should this. If you attack someone else and call _them_ bronze, then yeah, sure, some sort of punishment is in order. But not yourself.

Regardless, I still don't see why people who do worse things are given more chances and more warnings. And that someone with a 4+ clean record is given none.

> [{quoted}](name=SWATCOLE,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=E5VEhPeY,comment-id=0001000000000000,timestamp=2018-03-13T01:03:02.203+0000)If I was using it as an insult, then yes - you'd also be insulting the whole gay community.

The thing about slurs and hate speech is that those words DON'T have other uses. Sure, come communities have reclaimed them and re-purposed them, but it's still not something you throw around in public because *those words are inherently hateful at their core.*

And, again, the severity of this action is why there is no appeal, and there is no warning. Hate speech is NOT a minor offense. You are welcome to disagree, but this is not a policy I can see Riot softening or reversing ever.

Gay people took back "queer" and currently use "fa**ot" fairly often.  The use of such words does not offend me, and even if they did, they'd only be an expression of dislike.  Unless they actually say something like "kys you fa**ot" or something like that, I see no reason for punishment (and in that case, it would be because of they "kys").

I think people have just become too sensitive to naughty words (particularly on behalf of others).  I notice that oftentimes the biggest backlash against slurs does not come from a member of the insulted group.

> [{quoted}](name=Votable Jester,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=E5VEhPeY,comment-id=000100000000000000000001,timestamp=2018-03-13T03:37:58.830+0000)

It seems that anyone agreeing with me is just being downvoted. :/

 I 100% agree with you - it's _how_ you use the word that matters, not _that_ you used it. I think people reading this are just taking away that I want to be able to spam call people "%%%got" and not get punished for it - which I'm not. At all. 

If I call my teammate a "bronze piece of shit", I'll get warned or chat restricted (if punished at all), but if I change "bronze" to "%%%got", it's somehow now warranting of a 14 day ban. Both were said with the same intent, and both should be treated equally. Either 14 day ban both, or warn/chat restrict both. There shouldn't be that big of a disconnect when both essentially meant the same thing.

Let me put it this way:
If you say "John, you are a bronze piece of shit", you are insulting John.
If you say "John, you are such a Steve", using "Steve" as a stand-in for "bronze piece of shit", you are really insulting John **and** Steve, because the implication is that Steve is **the** archetypical bronze piece of shit.

The same thing applies when you call people a slur that is typically aimed at a specific group of people. By using something that originally refers to them as an insult, you reinforce the claim that the insult is making in the first place: That this group of people is inherently bad in some kind of fashion.

If you say "John, you are such a f%ggot", using "%%%got" as an insult, you are insulting John, as well as anybody who the word originally refers to.

Let's also not forget that you admitted yourself that you did actually not use it like a generic insult, but very directly used it to imply that a champion is gay.
You were directly using a slur against homosexuals to describe a homosexual; fictional or not. There's no "it depends how you use the word" excuse applicable here, because you yourself used it in a very offensive way.

So if someone said that a teammate who was doing super well was "amazing, like a fa**ot," would that not warrant punishment according to you?  After all, that's putting gay people in a positive light.

However that is not how it is treated here, the word itself is unacceptable here which will just keep it cemented forever as a divisive word between gay and straight people.

>So if someone said that a teammate who was doing super well was "amazing, like a fa**ot," would that not warrant punishment according to you?

Replace fa**ot with ni**er.
Do you think that would be acceptable?

Here's the deal: The word is still being used as an insult. You can pretend like it's a connotation-free word, but it simply is not. You yourself tried to defend its use as an insult in your previous post.
And the word is still being used to reference somebody's homosexuality. You yourself tried to defend using it that way in your OP.

Look, on a very very **very** basic level I agree with you: It does matter how you use a word. The problem is that you keep coming up with ways that are beyond any shadow of a doubt offensive in a public setting.
You want to talk about what cements this word as a divisive one? Frankly, it's people like you.

That was not how I (or really anyone) would use the word.  I was simply pointing out the error in your explanation of why it was bad.  You said it was wrong because it implied negative stuff associated to the group, by my example tied it to positive traits.  Despite being tied to positive traits, it would nevertheless be banned by Riot (which they have every right to).

My point was simply that punishment should be because of insulting someone rather than using a particular word.  I actually think the divisiveness of "ni**er" is a great example of why we shouldn't do that with "fa**ot."  Making a word unspeakable just ties it to greater division.

For example black people say "ni**er" all the time, but if a white person dared to say the word, it would get them kicked out of school.  This divides the groups to a degree because there is literally a difference in the language they can use.  I don't want this to be what happens with "fa**ot."

I fail to see how I make the word "fa**ot" divisive.  I never actually use the word myself, I'm gay (so if anyone should be offended by its use, it should be me), and I'm comfortable with people using the word so long as they aren't being truly homophobic (like saying "those fa**ots should all just drop dead").

It shouldn't be a word for polite conversation of course, but the same is true for curse words and insults in general.

Right off the bat: Sorry, I didn't check the name and thought I was still replying to the OP. That should explain and hopefully excuse the things I stupidly said about "you".

> You said it was wrong because it implied negative stuff associated to the group

It wasn't meant as a general reason as to why it's bad, and more as a specific reason why using it as an insult is worse than any other generic insult. There the negative association is there simply because an insult is inherently and intentionally negatively connotated.

The problem regarding the divisiveness is a tricky one. I will be honest, I don't really think I'm in a good position to argue on this, but in my opinion normalizing insults like these reinforces the divide just as much as banning them. 

Since you are **not** the OP, I'll rephrase what I said earlier in a more neutral way:
I agree that the way words are used matter. But when there is a huge amount of people who still use it with all its negative connotations the question arises whether it is worth the trouble differentiating between the cases.
After all, in real life you can read a person's body language and tone to determine how serious they are. In chat you do not have that luxury, meaning that if a word is used hateful most of the time, people tend to read it as hateful **all** of the time.

I guess I can agree on the basis that there are people who do still use it with the slur meaning.

I just really don't want it to go the same way as the n-word.

> [{quoted}](name=A Pretty Unicorn,realm=EUW,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=E5VEhPeY,comment-id=0009,timestamp=2018-03-13T21:22:51.976+0000)

I do not find it okay to normalize it as an insult. **Only if I am actively using the word, intending to cause emotional harm to you by insulting you for being gay, however.** Normalizing the word (exception of using it directly in an insult, insulting you for being gay) actually has the opposite effect. 
This is more of a social science thing, but when assign words as "do not say this ever", it actually gives more power to them. 

I'll give you an example. Back when TV first started, it was seen as completely taboo to show people who were married couples in movies/TV shows to even sleep in the _same bed,_ covers/clothes on and everything. It was seen as "too sexual and offensive". Over the years, however, it was shown more and more. Now, today, no one bats an eye to see full on sex scenes in movies. 
Why? 
When you repeatedly "censor" (not literally, but I hope you get what I mean) the word, you actually give it **more power.** I'm not saying you should therefore, to solve the problem, go around and call gay people %%%gots 24/7. That's homophobic. But by saying "you can't use the word, no matter the context", you're only contributing to the fact that it's seen as extremely offensive. 



Let me give another example. When we were all younger, cussing was a super "no go zone" for us. However, as we grow up and are exposed to cuss words more, even using them ourselves, they loose a lot of the initial "punch" that they had. Why? Repeated exposure lowered it. 



In psychology, it's common knowledge that the best way to get rid of one's fear is through constant exposure to said fear. The reasoning is the same as I stated in the last two examples. 



You find it offensive because you have attributed it to such a "high standard of offensiveness". **Once again, if I am directly insulting you for being gay by calling you a %%%got to intentionally cause harm through the word, then you have _every_ right to be offended. ** But simply using the word in a context that isn't an insult, and instead just tossing around the word should not be offensive, and the more you say it is, the more meaning you are giving it, and therefore, the more effect it will have.



All of that is unrelated to the simple point I made in the original post, which is why I didn't touch on it. The argument I made in my original post is that the context of if the word is as an intentional insult intending to cause harm should be why someone gets banned, not just that they said it in a sentence, but I guess this goes along with it. This is a fact that not a lot of people understand, thus we have the zero tolerance policy. I understand it will take a lot more than this simple reply for people to realize this fact, however, but I urge you to critically think about this and how although seeming counter productive, actually "helps" in the long run. 

If you still find you disagree with me, that's fine. Everyone is entitled to their own opinions. But you asked, and there's my answer.

I'd almost be on your side, like the way you used it in your own game didn't seem malicious or even accidentally harmful. But there are differences depending on how people use the word. Using it as an endearing term is very different from using it as a substitute for a negative term.

The "extreme example" was absolutely something that warranted a punishment. The person your friend reported said "I'm such a \___" as if being of that group of people is a bad thing. Honestly that's precisely the sort of thing that would genuinely hurt and offend another player in the same game who happens to be of that group of people.

Imagine how you would feel if every time somebody failed, they said "Wow I'm such a <insert _your_ name here>!" It's the sort of thing that would lead people to associate <insert _your_ name here> with being a failure. Do you see why this could be hurtful to people?
